title: Add product model
content:
This page explains how to add a product model record and a sub-product model record. To store the details of the product instances purchased by your customers, you must first add the corresponding product model.

Add product model

  1. Click  > Plan > Company.
  2. In the Companies dropdown, click Product Models. This directs you to the Product Models tab, which displays the list of product models added in the agent interface.
  3. Click Add a Product in the Product models pane.
  4. Specify the following product details:
    Field Description
    Display label The display label for the product.
    Publisher The company offering the product. 
    Product name The name of the product.
    Product line The specific product line to which the product belongs.
    Model type

    The model type of the product. The available options are:
    Bundle: A collection of multiple products that are packaged together and offered as a single unit to the user.
    Category: A classification or grouping of similar products.

    Product: An individual product.
    Product type The type of the product. The available options are Hardware, Service, and Software.
    Taxonomy
    An additional product classification. This field can be used for additional business logic and to filter data based on the level where the product is managed.
    The available options are:
    • Level 1 - Segment
    • Level 2 - Line of business
    • Level 3 - Product line
    • Level 4 - Portfolio name
    • Level 5 - Supported product 
    • Level 6 - SKU
    Description A description of the product.
  5. Click SAVE & EDIT.
  6. Specify the following additional details of the product:
    Field Description
    Parent model The parent model, if applicable. 
    Release date The date when the product was first released.
    End of life date

    The date when the product will not be supported or available.
    Owner group The group responsible for the product support.
    Owner The person responsible for the product support.
    Picture The product's image. For a software product, this can be the product logo or a screenshot.
  7. Specify the following identifying information for the product:
    Field Description
    SKU number The Stock Keeping Unit (SKU) number. It is a unique alphanumeric code assigned to each distinct product in inventory management. 
    UNSPSC code The United Nations Standard Products and Services Code (UNSPSC). It is a global classification system used for categorizing products and services across industries and sectors.
    Product Id A unique identifier for the product.
    EAN number The European Article Number (EAN). It is a unique barcode symbology used to identify retail products at the point of sale. 
    External reference The unique identifier or reference number used for mapping the product model record with external systems
  8. Specify the following sustainability details for the product:
    Field Description
    Location The location where the product was developed.
    Product lifetime (years) The lifetime of the product.
    Energy demand The energy required to produce a product, operate a software, or provide a service. 
    Lifetime usage emissions The total amount of gas emissions generated over the product's lifespan or usage period.
    Embodied emissions The gas emissions generated during the production, manufacturing, and transportation of the product.
    Recurring usage emissions The gas emissions that occur on a regular basis during use of the product or service.
    Emission recurring period The frequency at which Recurring usage emissions are generated.
    Total emissions The total amount of greenhouse gas emissions associated with a product or service.
    Unit The unit of measurement for emissions. Example, Kilograms (kg) of carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2e)
  9. Click Add attachment to upload product-related files.
  10. Click Save on the toolbar.
  11. Click Back on the toolbar to return to the Product Models tab. You can see the product model you created in the Product models pane. If you have specified a parent model, the newly added product model will be considered a sub-product of that parent. You can see it in the Sub-product models pane when the parent model is selected in the Product models pane

For more information about sub-product models and how to specifically add a sub-product model, see the Add sub-product model section.

Add sub-product model

A sub-product model can represent a specific variation of an existing product model. A sub-product model is treated exactly like a regular product model.

You can add a sub-product model under a product model, and each sub-product model can have its own sub-product model. In this way, you can build a hierarchy of sub-product models up to nine levels. You cannot add a sub-product model beyond the ninth level.

To add a sub-product model:

  1. Click  > Plan > Company.
  2. In the Companies dropdown, click Product Models.
  3. Click the product model record for which you want to add a sub-product model. The record will be highlighted in blue ,and the Sub-product models pane will be visible.
    You cannot add sub-product models beyond nine levels. If you select a product model at the ninth level, the Sub-product models pane will not be visible.

  4. Click Add a Product in the Sub-product models pane.
  5. Specify the following product details:
    Field Description
    Display label The display label for the product.
    Publisher The company offering the product. 
    Product name The name of the product.
    Product line The specific product line to which the product belongs.
    Model type

    The model type of the product. The available options are:
    Bundle: A collection of multiple products that are packaged together and offered as a single unit to the user.
    Category: A classification or grouping of similar products.

    Product: An individual product.
    Product type The type of the product. The available options are Hardware, Service, and Software.
    Taxonomy
    An additional product classification. This field can be used for additional business logic and to filter data based on the level where the product is managed.
    The available options are:
    • Level 1 - Segment
    • Level 2 - Line of business
    • Level 3 - Product line
    • Level 4 - Portfolio name
    • Level 5 - Supported product 
    • Level 6 - SKU
    Description A description of the product.
  6. Click SAVE & EDIT.
  7. Specify the following additional details of the product:
    Field Description
    Parent model The parent model field is auto-selected with the parent model of this sub-product model.
    Release date The date when the product was first released.
    End of life date

    The date when the product will not be supported or available.
    Owner group The group responsible for the product support.
    Owner The person responsible for the product support.
    Picture The product's image. For a software product, this can be the product logo or a screenshot.
  8. Specify the following identifying information for the product:
    Field Description
    SKU number The Stock Keeping Unit (SKU) number is a unique alphanumeric code assigned to each distinct product in inventory management. 
    UNSPSC code The United Nations Standard Products and Services Code (UNSPSC) is a global classification system used for categorizing products and services across industries and sectors.
    Product Id A unique identifier for the product.
    EAN number EAN stands for European Article Number. It is a unique barcode symbology used to identify retail products at the point of sale. 
    External reference The unique identifier or reference number used for mapping the product model record with external systems
  9. Specify the following sustainability details for the product:
    Field Description
    Location The location where the product was developed.
    Product lifetime (years) The lifetime of the product.
    Energy demand The energy required to produce a product, operate a software, or provide a service. 
    Lifetime usage emissions The total amount of gas emissions generated over the product's lifespan or usage period.
    Embodied emissions The gas emissions generated during the production, manufacturing, and transportation of the product.
    Recurring usage emissions The gas emissions that occur on a regular basis during use of the product or service.
    Emission recurring period The frequency at which Recurring usage emissions are generated.
    Total emissions The total amount of greenhouse gas emissions associated with a product or service.
    Unit The unit of measurement for emissions. Example, Kilograms (kg) of carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2e)
  10. Click Add attachment to upload product-related files.
  11. Click Save on the toolbar.
  12. Click Back on the toolbar to return to the Product Models tab.  The tab view is updated as follows:
    • The Product models pane (first pane) displays the newly added sub-product model.
    • The Sub-product models pane (second pane) allows you to add a sub-product model under the sub-product model you just added. Each sub-product model can have its own sub-product models.
    • The Product preview pane (third pane) shows the details of the sub-product model.
    • On the upper-left corner of the page, you will see the following breadcrumb:

      <Parent model> / <Child model>

      If you click on the Parent model link in the breadcrumb, you will return to the view showing the parent model.
